value.job_description: Under the direction of the Assistant Commissioner for Planning, the Director of Brooklyn Planning develops, implements, and manages all planning activities for the borough of Brooklyn.  The Director is responsible for building and managing a team of energetic, thoughtful, and engaged planners that work together to manage the project entitlement process and environmental reviews; and, ensure that development, design, and planning proposals meet HPD and other city policy objectives.    The goal of the Planning Division is to ensure that HPD investments are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  The Borough Planning units consist of teams of planners responsible for managing the entitlement and development approval process for the development of city-owned parcels and/or projects financed or sponsored by HPD for the development of affordable housing.    All planners in the Planning Division are expected to perform similar duties and responsibilities to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Borough Planning team include analyzing development trends, and neighborhood and market dynamics; land use and zoning analysis; coordinating with Predevelopment Planners in the requests for proposals review and selection process; and, managing the critical path toward project entitlement and development financial closing.  The Borough Planning team works collaboratively with other units of the Division of Planning and participates in neighborhood planning efforts.  The Borough Planning team works with other New York City agencies, such as the Economic Development Corporation and the Department of City Planning,  as well as for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents through the predevelopment process.  The Director of Brooklyn Planning, and all planners within the Division of Planning, is expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops as necessary.

value.job_description: The Division of Property Disposition and Finance seeks a Deputy Director for the Multifamily Disposition and Finance Programs. Under the supervision of and reporting to the Director of the Multifamily Disposition and Finance Programs, the Deputy Director will assist in the administration of two affordable housing programs: the Multifamily Preservation Loan Program (MPLP) and the Third Party Transfer Program (TPT). MPLP and TPT dispose and finance City-owned and recently foreclosed distressed properites to facilitate their rehabilitation and preservation as affordable housing. MPLP and TPT provide financing in the form of City Capital and federal HOME funds to leverage other financing sourcess, including Low Income Housing Tax Credits, tax-exempt bonds, and private debt and equity.     The Deputy Director will perform duties including, but not limited to the following:  Assist the Director with the development and implementation of plans, strategies and tools to effectively manage both programs.    Work with the Director to supervise and provide technical and procedural assistance to a staff of approximately six (6) project managers.    In conjunction with the Director, establish appropriate productivity measures for staff and goals and targets for the unit and work effectively with staff to achieve them.    Assist the Director in overseeing the prequalification process for entities eligible for designation as new owners of City-owned and recently foreclosed TPT properties; including drafting and issuing RFQs and evaluating applicants' experience and qualifications.    Identify property clusters for development and matching with qualified owner/developer.    In conjunction with the Director and project management staff, oversee preparation and review of development budgets, affordability analyses, design review and approval, tenant relocation and other pre-development issues to ensure timely construction loan closings.    Perform project management duties for all MPLP and TPT properties, including properties, not financed with City subsidies.    Represent the agency with tenants, developers, lenders, community groups, internal HPD divisions, and other City agencies.      Troubleshoot projects in construction, facilitate project completion and prepare recommendations for work-outs prior to permanent loan conversion.    Prepare reports, memoranda and written correspondence regarding both programs' performance and issues.    Coordinate special projects, conduct policy analyses, initiate research and make recommendations that relate to the management and operations of program.

value.job_description: The TLC is responsible for licensing and regulating for-hire vehicles in New York City. This includes taxis, livery cars, black cars, limousines, ambulettes, and commuter vans. Since the TLC's creation in 1971, the industries regulated by the TLC have grown to include more vehicles and drivers, and they provide more rides to the public than ever before moving over 1.25 million New Yorkers and visitors each day. On an annual basis, TLC-regulated vehicles provide transportation to 400 million people and generate over $4 billion in private revenue.    The Office of Judgment Enforcement (OJE) maintains and processes all TLC Vehicle Seizure operations, including processing all paperwork relating to vehicle release. Additionally, OJE performs all TLC collections actions, and processes all TLC license suspensions for unpaid fines and missed court hearings.    The Seizure Coordinator will be assigned to the Enforcement/USB Unit, reporting to the Deputy Director of the Office of Judgment Enforcement.  Primary duties will be to manage the TLC's 3rd-party tow pound contract, including interfacing with the pound on a daily basis in order to ensure the keeping and maintaining accurate records of all vehicles seized by TLC, including monitoring storage times and locations, and keeping an accurate count of vehicles at any drop-off or storage location at any given time.  Duties will also include interfacing with the general public daily in order to efficiently and accurately process the release of vehicles seized by the TLC.  The successful applicant may also be assigned to multiple work locations and general office duties in the Office of Judgment Enforcement, as needed, on a day-by-day basis

value.job_description: The Special Federal Litigation Division of the New York City Law Department seeks an admitted attorney with three years or more of litigation experience to defend the City and its officials in civil rights cases brought in federal court in which police, district attorney or correction officer misconduct is alleged. This application-based program is offered annually and is comprised of an 8-month curriculum.  â€¢HPD Developer Program â€“ SBS and the NYC Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) partner to provide a specific cohort of M/WBEs in the affordable housing development industry with guidance in navigating this arena and resources in order to help them compete for HPD affordable housing project opportunities.  â€¢NYC Teaming â€“ SBS provides workshops, services and matchmaking events designed to assist M/WBEs partner with prime vendors, other M/WBEs or small businesses in order to be able to compete for new or larger contract opportunities.    â€¢NYC Goods and Services Mentorship Program â€“ SBS provides business management training, through business assessment, one-on-one mentorship and a custom-developed growth plan, in order to assist a specific cohort of professional services, standard services and goods M/WBEs build their capacity to more successfully compete for City contract opportunities. This application-based program is offered annually and is comprised of an 8-9-month curriculum.    â€¢Corporate Alliance Program â€“ SBS partners with 10 major corporations to provide education, training and mentorship on how to do business with large corporations in order to build their capacity and ability to take on public sector work. UNIT DESCRIPTION AND INTERN RESPONSIBILITIES:    The Court Assets Unit of the NYC Treasury Division serves as the fiduciary of funds collected by NYC courts for Cash Bail or Court & Trust Cases. The Court Assets team is responsible for the proper recording and reconciliation of court deposits, as well as the timely and accurate disbursement of funds. The Court Assets Unit also is responsible for the annual abandonment of unclaimed court funds to State of New York Comptroller's Office. value.job_description: The NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. DEP delivers more than 1.1 billion gallons per day of the highest quality drinking water to 8.3 billion NYC residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and has a wastewater conveyance and treatment system capable of processing over 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day to protect the environment and the cityâ€™s surrounding waterways. The Bureau of Engineering Design & Construction (BEDC) currently has $10B of active construction contracts and another $3B of planning and design contracts under the responsibility and management of the bureau. The projects BEDC implement allow DEP as a whole to continue to operate and maintain an exemplary water supply system.    Under direction, the selected candidate will report to an Accountable Manager supervising multiple water and wastewater system projects within the watershed. These projects may include dams, aqueducts, wastewater treatment plants, bridges, roadways or other miscellaneous infrastructure projects. The candidate will be responsible for planning, coordinating and directing the implementation of the design and construction of capital projects in the NYC watershed.    This position will include the preparation, review and development of a number of capital engineering projects. This person will advise the client Bureaus in formulating project needs, options, and consequences, assuring that functional requirements are adequately articulated and that proposed projects fulfill these requirements.  Development of the project scope will include coordination and review of the drawings, specifications, conceptual estimates and schedules produced by consultants, contractors and in-house technical staff. All project documents will be prepared and reviewed in accordance with the BED&C Standard Operating Procedures and Department policies for Environmental Health and Safety.       The candidate must be able to demonstrate critical thinking skills and effective independent data analysis. The position requires excellent oral and written communication skills, ability to meet deadlines, and an ability to be flexible in assignment of work responsibilities.

value.job_description: Under the direction of the Director of Neighborhood Planning, the Planner undertakes all activities related to neighborhood planning for the preservation and development of housing in New York City neighborhoods.  The Planner is responsible for developing neighborhood plans, implementing meaningful neighborhood planning and civic engagement efforts, such as participating in and conducting community workshops, and assisting in developing agendas, managing logistics, and creating communication materials for the workshops.      The goal of the Division of Planning is to ensure that HPD investments are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  Neighborhood Planning consists of a team of planners responsible for developing, implementing, and managing all HPD activities related to neighborhood planning for the preservation and development of housing in New York City neighborhoods.    All planners in the Neighborhood Planning Unit are expected to perform similar duties to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Neighborhood Planning team include analyzing and resolving complex neighborhood planning and geo-spatial issues; performing basic housing, real estate, and demographic research; and undertaking neighborhood planning studies and developing implementation strategies in collaboration with other City agencies, such as the Economic Development Corporation, the Department of City Planning, and the New York City Housing Authority, and State agencies, for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents.  All Planners within the Division of Planning are expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops, as necessary.

value.job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day. value.job_description: The PMA Team   The Division of Performance Management and Analytics (PMA) works to improve New York City Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) operations through data integration, performance measurement, and analysis. value.job_description: The Nurse-Family Partnership (NFP) Program within the Bureau of Maternal, Infant and Reproductive Health is a nationally replicated nurse home visiting program that has been rigorously evaluated for over 30 years which has demonstrated significant improvements in pregnancy outcomes, parenting skills and family self-sufficiency. The NFP program began in NYC in 2003.  It is currently in all five boroughs and is the largest urban site in the nation.   DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:   Under supervision of the NFP Jamaica-site Supervisor, the NFP Nurse Home Visitor will:  -- Perform the following duties:, Apply the nursing process to assess the six prescribed NFP domains, including physical, emotional, social and environmental needs of women and their families as they relate to health and life course development.  -- Assist women and their families in establishing realistic goals and measurable outcomes; utilize reflective practice, stages of change, and other behavioral change approaches.  -- Provide counseling to assist women & their families in attaining targeted goals in areas including prenatal & postpartum care, nutrition, parenting, childcare, family planning, special health problems, housing, continuing education & employment, Evaluate women's & families' progress toward target goals, revise plan of care as appropriate.  -- Develop a working relationship with women and their families that promotes trust and problem solving.  -- Assist client in developing supportive relationships with family members and friends during pregnancy, birth and childcare.  -- Link women and family with community resources that are relevant to their specific needs, Consult and collaborate with other professionals providing service to women and their families.  -- Record nursing activities in a timely manner and in accord with project visit and institutional guidelines.  --Participate in ongoing learning in program implementation, Meet with supervisor for minimum of one hour per week.  -- Participate in weekly 2-hour team meetings and case conferences, Perform other related duties as needed.

The Registered Professional Nurse license and registration must be maintained for the duration of employment.    License Requirement:  A Motor Vehicle Driver license valid in the State of New York may be required for certain assignments.  If required, this license must be maintained for the duraion of assignment.

value.job_description: Under the direction of the Assistant Commissioner for Planning, the Director of Manhattan Planning develops, implements, and manages all planning activities for the borough of Manhattan.  The Director is responsible for building and managing a team of energetic, thoughtful, and engaged planners that work together to manage the project entitlement process and environmental reviews; and, ensure that development, design, and planning proposals meet HPD and other city policy objectives.  The goal of the Planning Division is to ensure that HPD investments are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  The Borough Planning units consist of teams of planners responsible for managing the entitlement and development approval process for the development of city-owned parcels and/or projects financed or sponsored by HPD for the development of affordable housing.  All planners in the Planning Division are expected to perform similar duties and responsibilities to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Borough Planning team include analyzing development trends, and neighborhood and market dynamics; land use and zoning analysis; coordinating with Predevelopment Planners in the requests for proposals review and selection process; and, managing the critical path toward project entitlement and development financial closing.  The Borough Planning team works collaboratively with other units of the Division of Planning and participates in neighborhood planning efforts.  The Borough Planning team works with other New York City agencies, such as the Economic Development Corporation and the Department of City Planning,  as well as for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents through the predevelopment process.  The Director of Manhattan Planning, and all planners within the Division of Planning, is expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops as necessary.
value.minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and four (4) years of full-time experience in city planning, at least eighteen (18) months of which must have been in a managerial capacity; or    2. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' above. However, a baccalaureate degree and eighteen (18) months of managerial experience in city planning is required of all candidates. Graduate work leading to an advance degree in city planning or related field may be substituted for up to two (2) years of the non-managerial experience on a year-for-year basis. Graduation from an accredited United States Law School may be substituted for two (2) years of non-managerial  experience.
value.preferred_skills: Candidates must have excellent writing, verbal and analytic skills.  Successful candidates will have thorough knowledge of New York City government and housing issues including specialized knowledge of City, State and Federal planning and environmental regulations and policies. value.job_description: The Division of Property Disposition and Finance seeks a Project Manager/Junior Underwriter/Analyst for the Affordable Neighborhood Cooperative Program (ANCP).  The Division of Property Disposition and Finance administers multiple loan programs: ANCP, Multi-family Preservation Loan Program, Third Party Transfer, and several small home repair and loan programs - which facilitate the rehabilitation of public and privately-owned multifamily buildings throughout New York City.  ANCP provides low-interest loans for the rehabilitation of occupied City-owned buildings.  After rehabilitation the buildings become affordable cooperatives for low and moderate income households. HPD provides subsidy through City Capital in addition to construction and permanent financing sources provided by, but not limited to: private institutional lenders, State of New York Mortgage Agency (SONYMA) and New York State Affordable Housing Corporation (AHC) programs.  At construction loan closing, HPD conveys properties to Restoring Communities HDFC (â€œRCâ€), a subsidiary of Neighborhood Restore.   RC will pass day-to-day operating authority for the rehabilitation of the project to a private developer, either for-profit or not-for-profit, selected through a Requests for Qualifications.  The developer is responsible for obtaining financing, temporarily relocating tenants, completing substantial rehabilitation of the property, and converting it to cooperative ownership. Following completion of rehabilitation, RC conveys the building to a cooperative housing corporation formed by the buildingâ€™s tenants.  Returning tenants purchase the cooperative interests attributable to their apartments for $2,500 per dwelling unit, while vacant units are sold for market prices to households with incomes not exceeding 120% AMI.  Under the direction of the ANCP Director and Senior Project Manager, the Project Manager/ Junior Underwriter/Analyst will be responsible for financial underwriting and project management for an assigned group of ANCP projects, including the loan commitment, loan closing, and construction phases. value.job_description: The NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is one of the nationâ€™s largest water and wastewater utilities, with 5,500 employees providing service to more than 8 million residents of New York City, and more than 1 million residents in Upstate New York. Reporting to the Chief Financial Officer (CFO), the Director of Strategic Sourcing will lead the planning, coordination, development and progress of strategic sourcing with the goal of achieving significant year-over-year reductions in the total cost of ownership (TCO) of goods and services procured while maintaining or improving product quality and vendor service levels by working closely with key stakeholders across the City and DEP to develop effective cost-reduction strategies and implementation plans, institutionalizing strategic sourcing across DEP and being directly responsible for the annual spending in these areas.     Specifically, the Director will:     Oversee the development and execution of strategies through the strategic sourcing process by guide strategic development for major commodities; overseeing the development of annual strategic sourcing plans; and communicating team progress with the CFO and senior business unit leaders.     Oversee the process to select and manage suppliers by driving relevant supplier selection and negotiating processes based on each commodityâ€™s sourcing strategy; and establishing and maintaining relationships with the senior management of key suppliers.     Measure and track internal performance within each spend category by tracking forecasted vs. actual savings and budget impact for the portfolio of commodities and communicate performance; and managing the development of data dashboards.      Monitor strategy implementation by coordinating and communicating overall sourcing trends/ results of commodities to the CFO and business unit leadership.     Drive annual productivity improvements in each spend category by developing and ensuring the implementation of ideas to optimize total cost of ownership for spend categories within the portfolio.     Develop an expertise in the portfolio spend categories by remaining current with market trends through relationships with vendors, experts, and the market broadly.       Identifying/defining sourcing best practices both within and outside of DEP and ensuring that those best practices are widely adopted by DEP's business groups.     Integrate commercial mindset purchasing into core business processes by working actively with key stakeholders in operating business units..     Uphold internal and external policies, regulations and laws by maintaining a working knowledge of applicable laws, regulations and internal policies (e.g., code of ethics) or procedures; and developing and maintaining a close working relationship with DEP Chief Contracting Officer and citywide purchasing personnel.

The Account Manager will oversee a portfolio of several City agencies and will be responsible for the monitoring and oversight of the strategies which have been broadly laid out for agencies to increase M/WBE utilization. value.job_description: Hiring Rate: $66.45 Per Hour (Flat Rate)  On-Board Rate After One Year: $71.18 Per Hour  (Flat Rate)    Healthy Start Brooklyn (HSB) is a federally funded program to reduce infant mortality, improve maternal-infant health, and reduce health disparities.  In New York City, neighborhoods in Central Brooklyn experience disproportionately high rates of infant mortality and low birth weight babies compared to other areas of the city.  HSB is a multi-year grant that supports the provision of services and the coordination of community response to address these important public health disparities.  The grant is awarded by the federal Health Resource Services Administration (HRSA) to the Fund for Public Health in New York (FPHNY) on behalf of and in partnership with the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH).    Position Overview:  The Medical Director is a part-time position, two days a week. The Medical Director (MD) will be responsible for providing a clinical perspective on the work of Healthy Start Brooklyn. In particular, the MD will be concerned with two of the five Healthy Start approaches: improving womenâ€™s health and promoting quality services. The MDâ€™s duties will include but not be limited to the following:    Administration and Service Delivery  --	Lead HSBâ€™s efforts in insurance enrollment, reproductive life planning, infant mortality, pre/inter-conception health, and other medical initiatives.'     --	Assist with Healthy Start Brooklynâ€™s placed-based efforts, including development of the Healthy Start Zone in Brownsville.    --	Collaborate on collective-impact efforts through the Community Action Network.    --	Share expertise in process, program, and evaluation with HSB mentees    Strategic Planning and Program Development   --	Build relationships with clinical providers in the HSB program area, including hospitals, clinics, OB-GYNs, pediatricians, and family physicians.    --	Develop a community-based research and strategic planning process around coordinated, sustainable systems of care.    --	Convene other city, state, and federal agencies and programs to collaborate on MCH-related initiatives affecting the grantâ€™s target populations and communities.    --	Collaborate with other divisions of the Brooklyn DPHO and the DOHMH to promote initiatives that target shared goals and objectives.    --	Represent HSB at federal, state, city, and local events and meetings.    --	Participate in the development and implementation of the Healthy Start Institute, standard curriculum, and Collaboration and Innovation Improvement Network (CoIIN). value.job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. Responsibilities will include: to skillfully adjust, calibrate, service, maintain, repair, program and calculate parameters, test automatic controls and instrumentation including telephone and radio equipment, supervisory control and data acquisition systems (SCADA), programmable logic controller (PLC), gas monitoring systems, automatic chemical dosing system, data recorders, variable frequency drives, analyzers, level meters, fire alarm system, intercoms, security systems, and other related instrumentation; utilizing computer and server resources directly related to instrumentation equipment signal performance, i.e. SCADA related workstations, application software, and network transmission components; utilizing a variety of testing devices and software diagnostic routines to troubleshoot, diagnose, repair and/or adjust instrumentation and micro-computer based data acquisition control system equipment, including manometers, timers, potentiometers, magmeters, multimeters, current loop generators, pressure gauges, digital and frequency counters according to manufacturer's recommendations, and assisting higher level technicians in more complex repairs and other work as needed; monitoring and maintaining spare part inventory for plant instrumentation and control equipment; utilizing the CMMS to track inventories, issue parts and equipment, and order equipment; overseeing the maintenance of critical equipment to ensure maintenance is prioritized and that equipment reliability is maximized; supervising and overseeing the installation, setup and calibration of instruments, controls, telemetric equipment and related equipment by outside contractors; adhering to and complying with all environmental, health and safety laws, agency policies, rules and regulations; reading and interpreting wiring schematics, mechanical drawings and specifications as necessary to install, service, and/or repair equipment in accordance with related regulations; supporting the annual budget review to provide estimates of labor, materials and supplies required.

value.business_title: HIV Incidence and Resistance Analyst, Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control
value.job_description: Hiring Rate: $56,555.00 (Flat Rate) Hiring Rate After One Year: $62,210.00 - $68,431.00 (Annual)  NYC has the largest, oldest and most diverse HIV epidemic in the United States. To reduce HIV transmission and HIV-related morbidity and mortality, accurate case surveillance data are required to guide public health decision-making and to allocate resources for HIV prevention and treatment and support services for HIV-infected persons.  Surveillance data are primarily generated through legally mandated population-based HIV surveillance. The HIV Epidemiology and Field Services Program of the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene processes >6,000 provider  and 800,000 laboratory reports annually, generating more than 12,000 field investigations, 2500 new diagnoses of HIV and 2,000 new diagnoses of AIDS each year.  In addition to standard case surveillance, the program conducts two important supplemental surveillance activities â€“ incidence and resistance surveillance.  Incidence surveillance uses a CDC statistical algorithm coupled with a laboratory test that can distinguish between early and chronic infection to estimate HIV incidence, thereby assisting the agency to track the numbers and characteristics of persons who are becoming infected now and permitting the targeting of prevention resources to hyperendemic populations. Resistance surveillance uses legally mandated nucleotide sequence reporting to track the prevalence of transmitted drug resistance among newly diagnosed persons and acquired resistance among those with established infections.    The program seeks a City Research Scientist I to assist the HIV Incidence and Resistance team with data management and analysis, estimation of incident infection (vs. incident diagnosis) and estimation of transmitted drug resistance.  This entry-level position provides a unique opportunity to learn the basic principles and complexities of HIV incidence and resistance surveillance and to work under the guidance of persons with experience and expertise.  The individual should have sufficient background in epidemiology, biology and viral genetics to grasp and apply the training and guidance that he or she will receive regarding the genetic structure of HIV, the science of reverse transcription, reproduction and integration of HIV into the host genome, the laboratory methods used to detect genetically mediated resistance, and the various statistical and laboratory methods used to estimate HIV incidence.  The individual will work directly with and under the guidance of the HIV Incidence and Resistance coordinator and principal investigator.  With intensive supervision and training, the individual will perform the following duties:  management and analysis of project data, collaboration with medical providers, laboratory managers, and other bureaus within the NYC DOHMH, project administration, grant-writing, laboratory and data quality assurance, and preparation of datasets for importing into the HIV registry, for monthly transmission to CDC, and for epidemiologic analysis.  The individual will:    1.	Assist the project coordinator with outreach  to the New York State Department of Health on issues regarding the regular transmission and format of encrypted genotype data through the NYS Health Commerce system (HCS).  2.	Assist the project coordinator with outreach to laboratories on regular ongoing submission of remnant specimens to NYC.  3.	Assist the project coordinator with liaison activities to NYS Wadsworth Laboratory on directly submitted and cross-jurisdictional incidence specimens.  4.	Assist in the  implementation, evaluation and monitoring, and modification, if needed, of new CDC incidence and resistance management systems.   5.	Assist with managing, cleaning, and verification of  incoming data files, including monitoring quality and completeness.  6.	Learn to match incidence and genotype data to case records in registry and its multiple feeder databases.   7.	Learn to monitor

The newly created Center for Health Equity (CHE) will align efforts in advancing health equity across the city and ensure that we deploy resources to reduce health and mental health disparities across all neighborhoods in New York City.  The CHE will work in collaboration with community-based partners, building on work the District Public Health Offices and others have pursued over the years. value.job_description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner investigates cases of persons who die within New York City from criminal violence, by accident, by suicide, suddenly when in apparent health, when unattended by a physician, in a correctional facility or in any suspicious or unusual manner or where an application is made pursuant to law for a permit to cremate a body of a person. value.business_title: Epidemiologic Liaison, Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control
value.job_description: NYC has the largest and most diverse HIV epidemic in the United States. To effectively reduce HIV transmission and HIV-related morbidity and mortality, accurate data are required to guide public health decision-making.  HIV/AIDS surveillance data are used to guide the allocation of millions of dollars in federal, state and city resources targeted for HIV prevention as well as treatment and support services for HIV-infected persons.  New York City prevention, treatment and care resource allocation recommendations are developed by two planning bodies composed of representatives of government agencies, non-governmental experts, patient representatives and advocates, and community-based organizations.  The HIV Epidemiology and Field Services Program, which maintains the HIV/AIDS Registry and monitors the epidemic in New York City, provides data, reports, interpretation and counsel to these planning bodies.   The federal prevention portfolio is allocated by the HIV Prevention Planning Group (HPG), and the federal treatment and care portfolio is allocated by the Ryan White Planning Council (RWPC).   Each group has a community and government co-chair and members representing governmental and non-governmental agencies and interests.    The HIV Epidemiology and Field Services Program is recruiting a senior scientist to serve as its Epidemiologic Liaison to these planning groups.  The individual will report to the programâ€™s Deputy Director and will work closely with the HIV Surveillance Unit and Research Unit to manage the provision of timely and useful reports and presentations to the planning bodies and their various special-issue committees.  The Epidemiologic Liaison will also work closely with personnel in the Bureau of HIV Prevention and Control who manage the federal grants and the planning bodies, the Director of Community Planning and the Director of Care and Treatment Services, as well as with the government co-chairs of the PPG and RWPC.  Responsibilities include ensuring that expressed needs for data and interpretation, including reports and oral presentations, are met (and anticipated), and that the two planning bodies have the support they require for adequate interpretation of the data and data-driven allocation of their grant dollars.  The position requires epidemiologic expertise, knowledge of and experience in using and analyzing NYCâ€™s surveillance registry, skill in writing and public speaking, and expert management of questions and concerns about the meaning of data from persons of varying backgrounds.    Wisdom and perspective on the history of the AIDS epidemic in NYC is needed to interpret current trends, as is knowledge of state-of-the-art prevention science and HIV treatment and care guidelines.      Duties will include:  --	Working closely with bureau and HPG/RWPC management to develop a calendar of annual reports and presentations and to ensure that data needs are met..    --	Advising bureau and HPG/RWPC management of the scope, methods of data collection and analysis, completeness and accuracy, and availability of data that they can expect to have at their disposal.    --	Attending HPG and RWPC plenary meetings as well as meetings of selected committees within each planning body.    --	Regularly, and as needed or requested, presenting data from surveillance and research studies to the HPG, RWPC, and committees through oral presentations; providing assistance with interpretation.       --	Working with bureau staff to produce grant applications for federal prevention, treatment and care funding, providing epidemiologic data and tables for narratives where required, and producing any support documents focusing exclusively on epidemiologic data., for example, the annual Epidemiologic Profile.    --	Writing appropriate SAS code and producing the statistical reports needed by the planning bodies.         --	Overseeing analyses and publication of reports and data directed exclusively toward the planning bodies;
